title: What are some benefits of face-to-face communication over telephone communication? - Quora

response.answer_text: Although there are many benefits of face-to-face communication, several that stand out are based upon “physiognomy” which allows a person to gather visual information from another. Visual feedback isn’t possible by phone. A definition indicates some benefits: “PHYSIOGNOMY is the art of discovering temperament and character from outward appearance.” In other words, “PHYSIOGNOMY is the composite revealed by facial features which show the qualities of mind or character by their configuration or expression.” With that in mind, suppose you’re the leader of a strong nation speaking with the leader of a weak nation in trouble. It might be military, industrial, economic, high tech, education, communication, political, whatever. Suppose also that the troubled nation has an abundance of SILVER, a critical natural resource which you, as your nation's leader, recently learned is now in DANGEROUSLY SHORT SUPPLY in your home country. The troubled nation’s leader—call him “Tony”— doesn’t know that. And Tony's been warming up to another nation’s leader—a real badass dictator, Lucifer, who’s hated by the world community. YOU NEED SILVER. Tony’s got it. Lots of it! Lucifer needs silver, too (which you learned just yesterday from your Intel team). You want to buy a MASSIVE amount (Tony’s ENTIRE available supply), at a price that’s fair to both nations. And all this is coming to a head, right now at his office, face-to-face. You’re watching Tony. You see he's nervous. You’re not sure why. But he’s really upset about something. You think it’s Lucifer who’s been talking to Tony. Lucifer lies a lot. You’ve got to know what’s going on (without Tony’s usual confusing bullshit). You like him. But he’s like a soup sandwich: all over the place! In your mind, five things are certain: 1. Tony absolutely hates pressure which he never gets from you. It's your patience. He likes that. You’re always kind with him. 2. His nation needs a lot of money — badly! 3. Your nation needs a lot of silver — badly! 4. Lucifer will outbid you in a heartbeat by buying at a high price from Tony because of the collateral crap he’ll create which exacts a vicious price down the road. (He’ll pay big today and suck Tony's blood dry tomorrow!) 5. Tony's nation has other natural resources of tremendous value to engineering, high tech and aviation. Tony doesn’t know that. And you don’t want his allegiance to shift to Lucifer. Right now you want to do business with Tony for the silver you need now — badly. You don’t want Tony to do business with badass Lucifer. In just a few minutes you’re going to see what Tony’s thinking about doing business with you — or selling his entire supply to Lucifer. Yes, you know you can buy from other silver mining nations. But Tony's a good guy — dumbern’ a brick — but you like him! And because of his nation’s other resources, its important to preserve his allegiance to you (and not lose it to Lucifer). [The 1st question you ask implies that your nation owns a very large supply of silver] [You ask and watch. Then you hit him with a second question, and a third] “Tony, I plan to call Lucifer tomorrow. My people tell me he wants to buy silver — by that I mean a lot of it. Why should I sell to him?” [Tony's reaction is an unmistakeable double-take; his eyebrows go up; and his face sweats] [Because you could act as a re-seller for other silver supplying nations, you’ve not lied. But you ARE shaping Tony's thoughts] “Tony, if Lucifer offered to pay fifty percent more than I’d pay—and you sold to him—how could he afford to do that? The world's spot price is the world's spot price. I’m asking because what he might want from you down the road could hurt. It could hurt a lot! Having done business with him in the past, did he ever hurt you and/or your nation? By the way, for reasons of confidentiality, you don’t have to answer that.” [Tony fidgets; looks down at the floor; then looks up with a guilty look on his face and says, “I’m sorry. I can’t talk about it.”] “Tony, what I’m going to tell you now is worth considering. You should know that my nation is among the world’s leaders in high tech, engineering, wind energy generation and aviation. My Intel people tell me that we need resources that we just don’t have. Your nation has them in amounts you might find shocking. I’m referring to vast amounts of Copper, Gallium, Phosphorus, Indium, Dysprosium, Terbium and Neodymium. Are you aware that your nation has the world's largest supplies of those seven, some of which are classified as “rare earth elements; and that a long-term strategic partnership of your nation and mine can benefit both? Before you answer, as my nation’s leader I’m empowered to enter into an agreement with you today to buy the seven elements as a package with your ENTIRE available supply of silver. Here's the agreement reduced to a three-paragraph executive summary. You’ll note that we’re prepared to pay one hundred billion dollars now as a down payment and more over the next ten years.” “I know your recent re-election wasn’t easy. What we’re talking about now are resources based on economics. But we both also know it can very favorably impact politics. By that I mean if an agreement into which we enter—an agreement governing natural resources—helps both of our countries, then it certainly can impact the opinions of our respective citizens. Please take a moment to read it and tell me what you think. What I think is that both our nations will be most grateful if we use our respective resources well and wisely. But go ahead and read what it says.” [Tony reads the executive summary; looks up with great surprise; opens his mouth (no words come out) but finally (quietly) says] “Am I correct in saying that you’ll buy our silver and the other seven for half a billion dollars now — and more as we mine?” [To which I warmly smile and say] “Yup!” [At which point Tony stands up and walks over indicating he’s eager to shake hands. I stand up, we shake hands and Tony does something amazing: he shows tears of gratitude] [That’s physiognomy!] [And so much for Lucifer!]

In a way this is increasingly an old technology question as the increasing use of video for personal and business calls means that face to face and telephone interactions are moving closer. They still aren’t the same, as one highly surprising fact shows: we are more able to tell if someone is lying or not telling the truth - and they are different - if we use voice over the telephone rather than meeting someone face to face. (I think it’s something to do with our ability to control our body language face to face, as we’re all pretty good at acting, and over the phone our guard goes down.) Even against video phone calls, face to face is a highly different experience still partly, I’ve come to think, because we’re still phased a little by the technology. So face to face is still an important element in understanding someone else because your entire focus face to face is on the other person. Through a video screen, you are not so engaged - I mean you can’t do your emails as you do on those interminable transatlantic telephone conference calls, but you do have other distractions that you don’t have face to face. I still recommend that any serious initial meeting is held face to face because the richness of information is so much higher - both for you and the person you are meeting. That’s the point.
